entries: Choose a damage type; acid, cold, fire, force, lightning, necrotic, poison, psychic, radiant, or thunder. The chosen type determines the dragon's damage immunity and the damage type for several other traits.
If the dragon gains immunity to poison damage from this trait, it is recommended that it also gains immunity to the poisoned condition.

trait.name: Destructive Maw (Mauler Only)
entries: The dragon deals an extra {@dice 1d6} damage with its bite attack. The extra damage is of the type associated with the dragon's Draconic Essence trait.

trait.name: Enhanced Attacks (Mauler Only)
entries: The dragon has a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with its bite attack.

trait.name: Enhanced Breath Weapons (Breathmaster Only)
entries: The dragon has +1 bonus to the DC for its breath weapons.
In addition, if the dragon can cast spells, it has a +1 bonus to its spell save DC.

trait.name: Enhanced Defence (Relentless Only)
entries: The dragon has a +1 bonus to its Armor Class and saving throws.

trait.name: Relentless Endurance (Relentless Only, Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If damage would reduce the dragon to 0 hit points, it instead drops to 1 hit point.

action.name: Breath Weapons {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon uses one of the following breath weapons.

items.name: Dragon Breath
items.entry: The dragon exhales destructive energy in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The damage is of the type associated with the dragon's Draconic Essence trait.

items.name: Secondary Breath (Breathmaster Only)
entries: The dragon has a second breath weapon (chosen when the dragon is created) from the Secondary Breath Weapons table below.

When the dragon uses its secondary breath, it makes an exhalation in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 13} saving throw, the type of which is determined by the type of breath weapon. On failed save, a creature is subject to the associated effect shown in the table.

rows: On a failed save, the creature the creature is either {@condition blinded} or {@condition deafened} (dragon's choice) for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, removing the condition
On a failed save, the creature is moved 15 feet towards or away from the dragon (dragon's choice).
On a failed save, the creature is {@condition incapacitated} for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, removing the condition on a success.

On a failed save, the creature the creature is either {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} by the dragon (dragon's choice) for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, removing the condition on a success.
On a failed save, the creature falls {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute. This effect ends for a creature if the creature takes damage or someone uses an action to wake it.

On a failed save, the creature must subtract {@dice 1d6} from any attack rolls or ability checks it makes for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

variant.name: Custom Dragons
entries: This statblock is designed to be used to create dragons to fit your worlds and stories. You are encouraged to add your own flavor to each dragon you create, possibly even adding additional text to certain traits. For example, a dragon with Immobilizing Breath could be exhaling frost to freeze creatures in place, slowing time in the area or filling the area with an incapacitating toxin.

entries: The dragon beats its wings. Each creature within 10 feet of the dragon must succeed on a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw or take 14 ({@damage 2d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. The dragon can then fly up to half its flying speed.

headerEntries: The dragon casts one of the following spells, requiring no spell components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 20}):

entries: The dragon deals an extra {@dice 2d10} damage with its bite attack (included in the attack).

trait.name: Enhanced Attacks
entries: The dragon has a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with its bite, claw and tail attacks (included in the attacks).

trait.name: Construct Design
entries: The dragon is immune to disease. It also does not need to eat, drink, breathe or sleep and magic cannot put it to sleep.

trait.name: Energy Conduit
entries: When the dragon would take lightning damage, it can use a reaction to absorb part of the energy for a future attack. When the dragon next deals damage of the same type before the end of its next turn, it can deal an extra {@dice 2d6} damage of the same type.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The dragon is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

optionalfeature.name: Alternative Abilty Scores
entries: Some dragons may find their power in the gathering of knowledge rather than the strength of their personality. For example, a papyrus dragon's greatest strength is its vast knowledge. As such, its Intelligence and Charisma scores are swapped to better reflect its nature.

Swap the dragon's Intelligence, Wisdom or Charisma score for that of a different ability from the same list.  The DC for the dragon's traits (excluding spellcasting) do not change as a result of theis trait.

optionalfeature.name: Alternative Creature Type
entries: Sometimes, just because it looks and acts like a dragon, doesn't mean it it actually is one. For example, a tree dragon's soul is bound to a specific tree and it is made of awakened wood. As such, its creature type is plant rather than dragon.
Change the dragon's creature type to another of your choice.

optionalfeature.name: Bad Flier
entries: Not all dragons are good fliers, the dragon may have damaged wings or be inexperienced with them. For example, a cave dragon may have never had the space to properly utilize its wings, leading them to atrophy.
Half the dragon's flying speed and add the follwoing trait to the dragon's statblock:
{@b {@i Bad Flier.}} The dragon falls at the end of each of its turns if the only thing holding it aloft is its fly speed.

optionalfeature.name: Burrower
entries: Some dragons are adept at digging through loose earth. For example, a desert dragon can burrow through sand dunes as easily as it can walk on top of them.
Add a burrowing speed to the dragon's statblock equal to the dragon's walking speed.

optionalfeature.name: Charming Presence
entries: Some dragon may be more alluring than terrifying. For example, a siren dragon might sing to charm those around it.
Creatures who fail the saving throw against the dragon's Frightful Presence trait are {@condition charmed} rather than {@condition frightened}.

optionalfeature.name: Climber
entries: Some dragons are adept at scaling vertical surfaces. For example, a ram dragon can traverse mountain cliffs as easily as gentle plains.
Add a climbing speed to the dragon's statblock equal to the dragon's walking speed.

optionalfeature.name: Construct Design
entries: The dragon may have been constructed by magic or science, rather than born. Or perhaps it is composed primarily of inorganic matter. For example, a stone dragon is powered by magic rather than biology, and so is a contruct rather than a dragon.
Make the following changes to the dragon's statblock:

items: The dragon's creature's type is contruct rather than dragon.
The dragon is immune to poison and psychic damage.
The dragon is immune to disease and the {@condition poisoned} condition.
The dragon does not need to eat, drink, breathe or sleep and magic cannot put it to sleep.

optionalfeature.name: Diver
entries: Some dragons are adept at swimming. For example, a ram dragon can traverse mountain cliffs as easily as gentle plains.
Add a swimming speed to the dragon's statblock equal to the dragon's walking speed. Also, add the following trait:
{@b {@i Amphibious.}} The dragon can breathe air and water.

optionalfeature.name: Draconic Mount
entries: For a multitude of reasons, a dragon may serve as the mount of another creature. For example, a cavalry dragon has bonded with a knight and the pair are a formidable force on the battlefield.
Add the following reaction to the dragon's statblock:
{@b {@i Protect Rider.}} When an attack would target a creature mounted on the dragon, the dragon can use a reaction to force the attack to target it instead.

optionalfeature.name: Energy Conduit
entries: You may decide that a dragon is not only unarmed by certain damage types but can channel the energy into its own attacks. For example, a lava dragon can absorb the heat from lava flows and direct it towards its enemies.
Add the following reaction to the dragon's statblock:

{@b {@i Energy Conduit.}} When the dragon would take damage of a type associated with its Draconic Essence trait, it can use a reaction to absorb part of the energy for a future attack. When the dragon next deals damage of the same type before the end of its next turn, it can deal an extra {@dice 2d6} damage of the same type.

optionalfeature.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: Not all dragons trace their origin to the material plane. For example, a fairy dragon may trace their origin, at least in part, to the feywild
Make the following changes to the dragon's statblock:

items: The dragon's creature's type is fey rather than dragon.
The dragon is immune to the {@condition charmed} condition.
Magic cannot put the dragon to sleep.

optionalfeature.name: Grounded
entries: Not all dragons can fly, either losing the ability to do so or never having it to begin with. For example, a gladiator dragon may have had its wings removed as a wyrmling to prevent it escaping the arena.
Remove the dragon's base flying speed.

optionalfeature.name: Hidecarved
entries: Some dragons carve magical runes on their scales to improve their resilience. For example,
The dragon has one or more Hidecarved Wards, described in chapter 3 of Fizban's Treasury of Dragons.

optionalfeature.name: Immutable Form
entries: A dragon's physical form may be unchangeable. For example, an animated dragon statue cannot have its form physically changed.
Add the following trait to the dragon's statblock:
{@b {@i Immutable Form.}} The dragon is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

optionalfeature.name: Iron Will
entries: Some dragons posses extrodinary willpower, or none at all. For example, a zombie dragon is no longer truly conscious and cannot be manipulated.
The dragon is immune to the {@condition charmed} and {@condition frightened} conditions.

optionalfeature.name: Minion Master
entries: Some dragons prefer to have underlings work for them. For example, many dragons may command {@creature kobolds|MM|kobold}, however, a forest dragon might command {@creature awakened tree|MM|awakened trees}, or a royal dragon might command dragonborn {@creature knight|MM|knights}.
Choose an appropriate creature that has a CR that is equal to or less than one third of the dragon's own CR. Then add the following action to the dragon's statblock:

{@b {@i Minion Master.}} {@dice 1d4+1} of the chosen creature appear in spaces within 30ft of the dragon. The summoned creatures act as a group immediately after the dragon's turn in initiative and will obey any commands given by the dragon (no action required). The creatures last until they die, are dismissed by the dragon (no action required) or the dragon uses this action again.
Additonally, if the dragon has legendary actions or lair actions, you can allow the dragon to use this trait as a legendary action or lair action.

optionalfeature.name: Multiple Heads
entries: Some dragons have multiple heads. For example, a medusa dragon has multiple serpent-like heads extending from its neck.
Add the following trait to the dragon's statblock:

{@b {@i Multiple Heads.}} The dragon can take one reaction per turn, rather than only one per round. It also has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.

optionalfeature.name: Poison Fangs
entries: Some dragons can utilize poison to make their attacks more danagerous. For example, an underdark dragon may drink {@item drow poison|dmg}, and deliver the poison to the target of its next bite attack.
Add the following bonus action to the dragon's statblock:

{@b {@i Poison Fangs.}} The dragon can use a bonus action to coat its teeth with poison (as if they were a melee weapon). The next time the dragon hits a creature with its bite attack, that creature is subject to the effects of the poison.

optionalfeature.name: Quick Caster
entries: A dragon may be able to perform magic quickly. For example, an iron dragon can use a legendary action to harden its hide by casting {@spell blade ward|phb} on itself.
Add the following legendary action to the dragon's statblock:

{@b {@i Quick Cast.}} The dragon casts a spell it knows that has a casting time of one action or one bonus action. The number of legendary actions expended is equal to the spell's level (1 for a cantrip).

optionalfeature.name: Secondary Essence
entries: Some dragons possess affinity for multiple forms of destructive energy. For example, a thermal dragon has mastery of heat, both producing and removing it. Both fire and cold damage are associated with its Draconic Essence trait.
Choose a second damage type for the dragon's Draconic Essence trait. When the dragon uses its Dragon Breath or Destructive Maw trait, it choses which of the damage types to deal.

optionalfeature.name: Signature Spellcaster
entries: A dragon might be especially talented at particular spells. For example, a spider dragon can cast the {@spell web|phb} spell at will.

Choose up to 2 spells of 3rd-level or lower. The dragon can cast these spells at will, without providing material components. Intelligence, Wisdom or Charisma is the dragon's spellcasting ability (choose when you select this trait).

optionalfeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: Some dragons posses innate magical talents. For example, a black hole dragon may know spells such as {@spell magnify gravity|egw} and {@spell gravity sinkhole|egw}. Meanwhile, a divine dragon may know spells such as {@spell cure wounds|phb} and {@spell greater restoration|phb}.

Choose a number of cantrips and spells up to the dragon's proficiency bonus. The maximum level of each spell known depends on the dragon's age; cantrips only for wyrmlings, 3rd-level or lower for young dragons, 5th-level or lower for adults, 7th-lower or lower for ancients and 9th-level or lower for greatwyrms.

For each spell of 1st-level or higher, the dragon can cast it once per day. The dragon does not need to provide material components for cantrips or spells that it casts. Intelligence, Wisdom or Charisma is the dragon's spellcasting ability (choose when you select this trait).

optionalfeature.name: Telepathy
entries: Some dragons have telepathic abilities. For example, a psionic dragon can communicate with the minds of those around it.
Add the following trait to the dragon's statblock:
{@b {@i Telepathy.}} The dragon can speak telepathically with any other creature within 120ft.

optionalfeature.name: Unusual Size
entries: Some dragons are noticably larger or smaller than expected for their age. For example, a giant dragon may be significantly larger than normal dragons.
Increase or decrease the dragon's size category by one.

variantrule.name: Creating Custom Dragons
entries: A number of dragon statblocks exist, but sometimes you may want a more unique dragon to your world or stories. These rules seek to provide an easy way to build custom dragons when the existing statblocks do not fit. Remember that these are guidelines only and you may adjust anything as you see fit.
First, choose the dragon's age and select the respective statblock from the list below:

Within each statblock you will need to choose a damage type for its draconic essence trait. You will also choose a dragon form; Breathmaster, Mauler or Relentless, which determines certain traits in its stat block.

If you wish, you may then add a number of {@filter additional draconic traits|optionalfeatures|source=erlw;jackalope;caligos;phb;tce;xge;jdragon|feature type=draconic traits} to further distiguish the dragon.

entries.name: Example: Voltaic Dragon
entries: Voltan is a renowned enchanter and tinkerer who is a frequent target for thieves. He decides to build a dragon-like contraption to defend his vaults.
First, we decide the dragon's age. Since the party is 2nd-level and this is the first incarnation, we shall choose a {@creature Custom Dragon (Wyrmling)|JDragon|wyrmling}.
Second, we decide the damage type associated with its Draconic Essence trait. If we imagine the dragon being designed to electrocute intruders, we shall choose lightning damage.
Third, we decide the dragon's form. Since the dragon intends to slaughter intruders quickly, we shall choose Mauler.
Finally, we decide any addtional traits to add. Since the dragon was constructed and lacks emotion, we shall choose {@optfeature construct design|JDragon} and {@optfeature iron will|JDragon} traits.
Now we have a {@creature voltaic dragon (wyrmling)|JDragon} that should hopefully provide an interesting challenge for a low level party.

Over several decades, Voltan upgrades the dragon in various ways. Choosing different base statblocks and adding even more traits each time we end up with the statblocks for a {@creature voltaic dragon (young)|JDragon} and a {@creature voltaic dragon (adult)|JDragon}.

Voltan then decides to have the dragon upgrade itself, allowing it to outlive him. Over the next few centuries, the dragon begins hoarding magic items to enchance itself. Eventually, having exhausted the resources of its own world, the dragon heads out to the astral sea, harvesting the remains of dead gods. We can make the statblocks for the {@creature voltaic dragon (ancient)|JDragon} and the {@creature voltaic dragon (greatwyrm)|JDragon}
